page.title: 10HISTORY-KILMERSDON-CHARLTON
page.content: "Chenemersdone" in the Domesday book l086. The word meant "mere-stone" or boundary. Kilmersdon in the l9C - The Barracks - Built in l800, is now converted into three dwellings. Originally a workhouse and got its name when troops were quartered there during the Napoleonic Wars. On the 3rd floor the pauper children were taught to weave. The blind house - a square, stone, windowless little building with a stone conical roof. Once a lock-up, it is now used as a bus shelter. "White Gates" - Charlton. A mid-Victorian gate-screen, of classical Greek style, once formed the entrance to Charlton House, a Jolliffe residence demolished c. l950. A detailed survey of the manor of Kilmersdon was made in 1571 (reference should be made to this in studying the history of Kilmersdon).
